awd_titl_txt: EAGER: MAKER: Collaborative: Beyond Rubrics: Moving Towards Embedded Assessment in Maker Education
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is supported by the STEM+Computing (STEM+C) program, which advances applied research integrating computational thinking and computing activities within disciplinary science, technology, engineering, and mathematics teaching and learning in early childhood education through high school (PreK-12). Because of its fundamental focus on collaborative, iterative, process-based learning--key 21st century skills--maker education's learning outcomes cannot be adequately tracked by tests, the traditional means of assessment in classrooms. The project will develop embedded assessment techniques, co-designed with and implemented by teachers, to collect rigorous forms of evidence of student learning, without constraining or interrupting complex making processes. Embedded assessment refers to a form of assessment where assessment is directly incorporated into the learning environments and activities, so student learning can be monitored and supported in real time. Embedded assessment has been widely adopted in digital contexts to design tasks within a system that can elicit evidence of desired outcomes, and to automatically and rapidly capture rich data generated in the process of performance. Leveraging the same methodology in maker learning is promising, however hands-on learning environments do not have the same data affordances as digital environments. Through this necessary reframing and redesigning of assessment, we can begin to answer the question of how maker-centered learning can truly benefit the broader education system, both for students and for teachers. This knowledge will improve the quality of learning in school-based maker environments, and enable more schools to bring these valuable experiences to their students.

The project will develop and evaluate practices of embedded assessment in maker-centered learning which will lead to assessment practices better suited to the processes and desired outcomes of maker education. There are currently no well-documented assessment protocols or processes for maker education. The project will conduct design-based research that involves two lines of connected work. First, the project will iteratively develop embedded assessment toolkits with maker educators and teachers. Second, the project will establish a transformative process where participating teachers can successfully adopt embedded assessments within middle school STEM curricula.

por.por_cntn:
Over the past 5 years, maker-centered learning has grown rapidly through grassroots efforts and an open community of practice. Educators have been readily willing to share, learn, and make together. Having taken root in out-of-school-time environments like museums and after-school programs, maker-centered learning has bridged to formal classroom environments in the recent past. It has the high potential for fundamentally changing the walls, structures, and expectations of traditional, content-driven schooling. For maker education to take root in sustainable and meaningful ways, several factors must be addressed, including: administrative and community buy-in, teacher professional development, resource development, fundraising, curricular alignment, and student-grounded practices. In particular, questions around assessment and alignment of learning in school-based maker education stand as barriers to its spread in schools.

When assessment is done effectively, it allows teachers to demonstrate evidence of student learning. This evidence can lead to increased administrative support, additional resources, and further strengthening the impact of maker education. To bring about effective change in maker education, assessments of maker activities need to clarify what cognitive and non-cognitive skills are being learned and practiced, connect to existing competency frameworks, capitalize on current assessments of project-based learning, connect to other measurements of future ready skills, and be available for teachers to adopt and adapt.

With this support from NSF, The MIT Playful Journey Lab (playful.mit.edu) in collaboration with Maker Ed (https://makered.org/) aimed to address this gap by developing embedded assessment tools with two public middle schools. With a design-based research approach, the project (a) established design principles for embedded assessment in making to support better practices in school-based making (Murai, Kim, Martin, Kirschmann, Rosenheck, & Reich, 2019; Preprint can be retrieved from here: https://edarxiv.org/amvs2/ ) and (b) developed an assessment toolkit that can be adopted and adapted by teachers to assess maker competencies such as agency and troubleshooting (Kim, Murai, & Chang, in press. Preprint can be retrieved from https://edarxiv.org/4h3n7/).  The toolkit is downloadable from the Maker Ed’s website and resources page: https://makered.org/beyondrubrics/

The research findings from this project have been widely disseminated at domestic and international conferences that draw diverse audiences, from practitioners to researchers. The product developed from this project has also been widely accessed by educators, reaching 15,000 unique downloads since being published on the Maker Ed’s website in June 2019. This project demonstrates a step toward embedded assessment practices that educators can adopt in school-based making.
